This is a [Next.js](https://nextjs.org) project bootstrapped with [`create-next-app`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/cli/create-next-app).

## Getting Started

First, run the development server:

```bash
npm run dev
# or
yarn dev
# or
pnpm dev
# or
bun dev
```

Open [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) with your browser to see the result.

You can start editing the page by modifying `app/page.tsx`. The page auto-updates as you edit the file.

This project uses [`next/font`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/optimizing/fonts) to automatically optimize and load [Geist](https://vercel.com/font), a new font family for Vercel.

To learn more about Next.js, take a look at the following resources:

15.content:
Problem Statement

Contrastive learning methods such as CLIP rely on mini-batch contrastive loss, which introduces strong dependencies on batch size and limits scalability. Smaller batches reduce negative sample diversity, leading to slower convergence and degraded representation quality.

16.content:
Research Motivation

This project investigates how global contrastive objectives can better approximate the true optimization landscape of contrastive learning, decoupling performance from batch size while improving geometric alignment between image and text embeddings.

17.content:
Approach

  • Formulated contrastive learning using a global contrastive objective
  • Evaluated SogCLR and iSogCLR for stochastic optimization efficiency
  • Integrated CyCLIP to enforce geometric consistency across modalities
  • Analyzed temperature scaling effects on hard-negative adaptation

18.content:
Experimental Setup

  • Datasets: MSCOCO, ImageNet
  • Backbone: CLIP-style dual encoder
  • Metrics: retrieval accuracy, convergence speed

Key Results

  • Reduced sensitivity to batch size without loss of accuracy
  • Faster convergence compared to mini-batch CLIP baselines
  • Improved cross-modal embedding alignment

19.content:
Why This Matters

This work highlights how theoretical insight into optimization objectives can directly translate into practical training efficiency improvements. It reflects my interest in bridging learning theory with scalable ML systems.

) }

21.content:
Problem

Deepfake detectors often achieve excellent in-distribution performance but fail on new, unseen generation methods. This project frames the challenge as covariate shift: the input distribution changes across generators while the real-vs-fake task remains the same.

22.content:
Approach

  • Phase 1: Invariant Risk Minimization (IRM) to learn features that support a predictor optimal across training environments.
  • Phase 2: Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) on top of the IRM-trained backbone to enable fast adaptation to new environments.
  • Shared backbone: ViT-Small, with a custom VisionTransformerWithFrequency variant (FFT-based frequency branch).

23.content:
Datasets & Setup

  • Training source: FaceForensics (FF) using environments Original (real), DeepFakes, Face2Face.
  • OOD evaluation: CelebDF-v2 and DF40 (not used for training in the evaluation protocol described).
  • Frames extracted at 1 fps, resized 256×256, center-cropped to 224×224; augmentations include flips, blur, color jitter.
  • MAML episodes: 5-shot support, 15 query; 5 inner-loop steps; 300 meta-iterations; meta-batch size 4 tasks.

24.content:
Results (Cross-Dataset)

Method CelebDF AUC DF40 AUC
ERM

25.content: DF40 AUC ERM 0.5601 0.4950 IRM 0.5362 0.5049

26.content: IRM 0.5362 0.5049 DANN 0.5373 0.6140 Hybrid IRM + MAML 0.5895 0.6062

27.content:
The hybrid IRM+MAML framework achieved the strongest CelebDF cross-dataset AUC (0.5895) while maintaining strong in-distribution performance.

In-Distribution Performance (FF)

  • Validation Accuracy: 0.9319.
  • Validation ROC-AUC: 0.9817.
  • Validation PR-AUC: 0.9834.

28.content:
Engineering Notes

  • Built a robust data loader to handle truncated/corrupted frames and avoid training crashes.
  • Managed memory limits by freezing early ViT blocks and using mixed precision.
  • Kept a shared pipeline across ERM/IRM/DANN/hybrid to ensure fair comparisons.

29.content:
Next Steps

  • Increase environment diversity beyond limited FF splits to strengthen IRM invariance signals.
  • Extend to video-level temporal modeling (e.g., video transformers) for stronger cues beyond frame artifacts.
  • Explore continual updates for newly emerging generators without catastrophic forgetting.
); }

31.content:
Motivation

Most modern LLM applications assume persistent cloud connectivity and server-grade hardware. This project explores what it actually takes to run a capable language model fully offline on a consumer Android phone, under tight memory, latency, and power constraints.

32.content:
Design Constraints

  • Phone-realistic hardware (Testing on Samsung F15-class device)
  • ≤ 0.5B parameter model size
  • Offline-first, no network dependency
  • Low-latency token streaming
  • Memory-efficient inference

33.content:
System Architecture

The system uses MLC LLM to convert a pretrained transformer into a graph-compiled, INT4-quantized runtime optimized for ARM64. Inference runs natively through the Android NDK, with a thin JNI bridge connecting the model backend to a Kotlin-based chat UI.

{/* 
          Android UI (Kotlin) 
              ↓ JNI
          Native C++ Runtime
              ↓
          MLC Graph Executor
              ↓
          INT4 Quantized Model

34.content:
{/* 
          Android UI (Kotlin) 
              ↓ JNI
          Native C++ Runtime
              ↓
          MLC Graph Executor
              ↓
          INT4 Quantized Model
*/}

35.content:
Model & Optimization

  • Model: Qwen2.5-0.5B-Instruct
  • INT4 quantization (q4f16_1)
  • Graph-compiled execution (no interpreter loops)
  • ARM64 native runtime via Android NDK

36.content:
Performance

Tokens / second 5–8
RAM usage ~1.2 GB
Cold start latency

37.content: RAM usage ~1.2 GB Cold start latency ~4 seconds

38.content:
What This Demonstrates

  • End-to-end LLM systems engineering
  • Quantization-aware deployment
  • Mobile inference under real constraints
  • Bridging research tooling with production environments

39.content:
Next Steps

  • Streaming token JNI integration
  • KV-cache reuse across turns
  • Memory-mapped weights
  • Public APK release
) }

41.content:
Motivation

Rendering legible text in reconstructed 3D scenes is challenging under viewpoint changes, occlusions, and lighting. Vanilla Gaussian Splatting is fast but struggles on text-centric scenes; TextNeRF improves text synthesis but can be computationally heavy and scene-specific. This project explores a text-aware Gaussian Splatting framework (“TextGS”) for high-fidelity, real-time 3D text reconstruction.

42.content:
Method (TextGS)

  • Dataset: TextNeRF dataset (438 scenes, 12,520 images with camera poses).
  • Preprocess with COLMAP (camera estimation, feature matching, sparse point cloud) to initialize Gaussians.
  • Train for ~30,000 iterations (A30 GPU mentioned in the report).
  • Add a text-aware loss term using OCR output compared to ground-truth text via Levenshtein distance.
  • Use normalized text loss to stabilize across variable text lengths.
  • Rendering uses a pinhole camera model to improve clarity; targets real-time 30 fps at 1080p.

43.content:
• Use normalized text loss to stabilize across variable text lengths.
  • Rendering uses a pinhole camera model to improve clarity; targets real-time 30 fps at 1080p.

44.content:
Text Loss (High Level)

The training objective combines standard Gaussian Splatting image reconstruction losses with a text loss computed as the Levenshtein edit distance between OCR-extracted text from the rendered image and ground-truth text, including a normalized variant for robustness across string lengths.

45.content:
Quantitative Results

Method / Setting PSNR SSIM LPIPS

46.content: SSIM LPIPS TextNeRF (avg over 66 scenes) 28.96 0.822 0.147 3DGS Pinhole (Scene 15) 34.84

47.content: 0.147 3DGS Pinhole (Scene 15) 34.84 0.959 0.167 3DGS + Text Loss (Scene 15) 34.23 0.956 0.172

48.content: 3DGS + Text Loss (Scene 15) 34.23 0.956 0.172 3DGS + Normalized Text Loss (Scene 15) 34.92 0.961 0.162

49.content:
The normalized text-loss variant achieved the best reported quality on Scene 15 while preserving real-time rendering capability (30 fps at 1080p) described in the report.

OCR Model Choice

OCR quality directly affects the text loss. The report compares OCR engines and notes EasyOCR performs best on both original and cropped text images (WER/CER reported), motivating its use for the text-guided optimization.

50.content:
What This Demonstrates

  • Bridging 3D reconstruction and OCR by designing a text-aware optimization objective.
  • Experimental iteration: camera model choice (radial vs pinhole) materially impacts text fidelity.
  • Real-time constraints: optimizing for legibility while maintaining interactive rendering speed.

51.content:
Next Steps

  • Evaluate across more scenes (beyond the demonstrated examples) for stronger generality claims.
  • Explore better differentiable OCR surrogates / gradient estimators for improved end-to-end optimization stability.
  • Add text embeddings or richer priors into Gaussian parameters to improve robustness under extreme conditions.
); }

57.content: I like working end to end: understanding the theory behind a method, implementing it carefully,and carrying it through to practical use. This has led me to work on things like on-device LLM inference, efficient retrieval-augmented systems, and applied ML for scientific and healthcare domains.

58.content:
What motivates me most is not just making models work, but understanding why they work, and what breaks when assumptions change.

{/*
  • LLM inference and acceleration (quantization, kernel fusion, compilation, on-device and constrained deployment)
  • Full-stack RAG and VQA systems with retrieval, reranking, evaluation, and production monitoring
  • Applied ML for healthcare and scientific domains, translating research models into usable systems
*/}
